description: From Middle English strengthe, from Old English strengþu (“strength”), from Proto-West Germanic *strangiþu (“strongness; strength”), equivalent to strong +‎ -th. Cognate with Dutch strengte (“strength”), German Low German Strengde, Strengte (“harshness; rigidity; strictness; severity”).

entries.meaning: The quality or degree of being strong.
examples: It requires great strength to lift heavy objects.

entries.meaning: The intensity of a force or power; potency.
examples: He had the strength of ten men.

entries.meaning: The strongest part of something; that on which confidence or reliance is based.
examples: […]  certainly there is not in the world a greater strength against temptations, then is deposited in an obedient understanding  […] .
We all have our own strengths and weaknesses.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An armed force, a body of troops.

verbs.description: strength (third-person singular simple present strengths, present participle strengthing, simple past and past participle strengthed)
